Returns -1 if substring was not found.comparer is a Comparer which is used to control the comparison. Comparers can be used to provide case-insensitive or culture and locale-aware comparisons.The following built-in comparers are available in the formula language:Comparer.Ordinal: Used to perform an exact ordinal comparisonComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase: Used to perform an exact ordinal case-insensitive comparisonComparer.FromCulture: Used to perform a culture-aware comparison

name: Text.PositionOfAny
description: Returns the first position of any character in the list characters that is found in text. An optional parameter occurrence may be used to specify which occurrence position to return.
syntax: Text.PositionOfAny(text as text, characters as list, optional occurrence as nullable number) as any

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Find the first position of "W" or "H" in text "Hello, World!".UsagePower Query MText.PositionOfAny("Hello, World!", {"H", "W"})Output0Example 2Find all the positions of "W" or "H" in text "Hello, World!".UsagePower Query MText.PositionOfAny("Hello, World!", {"H", "W"}, Occurrence.All)Output{0, 7}

remarks: Returns the first position of any character in the list characters that is found in text. An optional parameter occurrence may be used to specify which occurrence position to return.

name: Text.Proper
description: Returns the result of capitalizing only the first letter of each word in text value text. All other letters are returned in lowercase. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US").
syntax: Text.Proper(text as nullable text, optional culture as nullable text) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Use Text.Proper on a simple sentence.UsagePower Query MText.Proper("the QUICK BrOWn fOx jUmPs oVER tHe LAzy DoG")Output"The Quick Brown Fox Jumps Over The Lazy Dog"

remarks: Returns the result of capitalizing only the first letter of each word in text value text. All other letters are returned in lowercase. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US").

name: Text.Range
description: Returns the substring from the text text found at the offset offset. An optional parameter, count, can be included to specify how many characters to return. Throws an error if there aren't enough characters.
syntax: Text.Range(text as nullable text, offset as number, optional count as nullable number) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Find the substring from the text "Hello World" starting at index 6.UsagePower Query MText.Range("Hello World", 6)Output"World"Example 2Find the substring from the text "Hello World Hello" starting at index 6 spanning 5 characters.UsagePower Query MText.Range("Hello World Hello", 6, 5)Output"World"

remarks: Returns the substring from the text text found at the offset offset. An optional parameter, count, can be included to specify how many characters to return. Throws an error if there aren't enough characters.

name: Text.Remove
description: Removes all occurrences of a character or list of characters from a text value. The removeChars parameter can be a character value or a list of character values.
syntax: Text.Remove(text as nullable text, removeChars as any) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Remove characters , and ; from the text value.UsagePower Query MText.Remove("a,b;c", {",",";"})Output"abc"

remarks: Removes all occurrences of a character or list of characters from a text value. The removeChars parameter can be a character value or a list of character values.

name: Text.RemoveRange
description: Returns a copy of the text value text with all the characters from position offset removed. An optional parameter, count can by used to specify the number of characters to remove. The default value of count is 1. Position values start at 0.
syntax: Text.RemoveRange(text as nullable text, offset as number, optional count as nullable number) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Remove 1 character from the text value "ABEFC" at position 2.UsagePower Query MText.RemoveRange("ABEFC", 2)Output"ABFC"Example 2Remove two characters from the text value "ABEFC" starting at position 2.UsagePower Query MText.RemoveRange("ABEFC", 2, 2)Output"ABC"

remarks: Returns a copy of the text value text with all the characters from position offset removed. An optional parameter, count can by used to specify the number of characters to remove. The default value of count is 1. Position values start at 0.

name: Text.Repeat
description: Returns a text value composed of the input text text repeated count times.
syntax: Text.Repeat(text as nullable text, count as number) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Repeat the text "a" five times.UsagePower Query MText.Repeat("a", 5)Output"aaaaa"Example 2Repeat the text "helloworld" three times.UsagePower Query MText.Repeat("helloworld.", 3)Output"helloworld.helloworld.helloworld."

remarks: Returns a text value composed of the input text text repeated count times.

name: Text.Replace
description: Returns the result of replacing all occurrences of text value old in text value text with text value new. This function is case sensitive.
syntax: Text.Replace(text as nullable text, old as text, new as text) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Replace every occurrence of "the" in a sentence with "a".UsagePower Query MText.Replace("the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog", "the", "a")Output"a quick brown fox jumps over a lazy dog"

remarks: Returns the result of replacing all occurrences of text value old in text value text with text value new. This function is case sensitive.

name: Text.ReplaceRange
description: Returns the result of removing a number of characters, count, from text value text beginning at position offset and then inserting the text value newText at the same position in text.
syntax: Text.ReplaceRange(text as nullable text, offset as number, count as number, newText as text) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Replace a single character at position 2 in text value "ABGF" with new text value "CDE".UsagePower Query MText.ReplaceRange("ABGF", 2, 1, "CDE")Output"ABCDEF"

remarks: Returns the result of removing a number of characters, count, from text value text beginning at position offset and then inserting the text value newText at the same position in text.

name: Text.Reverse
description: Reverses the provided text.
syntax: Text.Reverse(text as nullable text) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Reverse the text "123".UsagePower Query MText.Reverse("123")Output"321"

remarks: Reverses the provided text.

name: Text.Select
description: Returns a copy of the text value text with all the characters not in selectChars removed.
syntax: Text.Select(text as nullable text, selectChars as any) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Select all characters in the range of 'a' to 'z' from the text value.UsagePower Query MText.Select("a,b;c", {"a".."z"})Output"abc"

remarks: Returns a copy of the text value text with all the characters not in selectChars removed.

name: Text.Split
description: Returns a list of text values resulting from the splitting a text value text based on the specified delimiter, separator.
syntax: Text.Split(text as text, separator as text) as list

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Create a list from the "|" delimited text value "Name|Address|PhoneNumber".UsagePower Query MText.Split("Name|Address|PhoneNumber", "|")Output{    "Name",    "Address",    "PhoneNumber"}

remarks: Returns a list of text values resulting from the splitting a text value text based on the specified delimiter, separator.

name: Text.SplitAny
description: Returns a list of text values resulting from the splitting a text value text based on any character in the specified delimiter, separators.
syntax: Text.SplitAny(text as text, separators as text) as list

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Create a list from the text value "Jamie|Campbell|Admin|Adventure Works|www.adventure-works.com".UsagePower Query MText.SplitAny("Jamie|Campbell|Admin|Adventure Works|www.adventure-works.com", "|")Output{    "Jamie",    "Campbell",    "Admin",    "Adventure Works",    "www.adventure-works.com"}

remarks: Returns a list of text values resulting from the splitting a text value text based on any character in the specified delimiter, separators.

name: Text.Start
description: Returns the first count characters of text as a text value.
syntax: Text.Start(text as nullable text, count as number) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Get the first 5 characters of "Hello, World".UsagePower Query MText.Start("Hello, World", 5)Output"Hello"

remarks: Returns the first count characters of text as a text value.

name: Text.StartsWith
description: Returns true if text value text starts with text value substring.text: A text value which is to be searchedsubstring: A text value which is the substring to be searched for in substringcomparer: [Optional] A Comparer used for controlling the comparison. For example, Comparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase may be used to perform case-insensitive searchescomparer is a Comparer which is used to control the comparison. Comparers can be used to provide case-insensitive or culture and locale-aware comparisons.The following built-in comparers are available in the formula language:Comparer.Ordinal: Used to perform an exact ordinal comparisonComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase: Used to perform an exact ordinal case-insensitive comparisonComparer.FromCulture: Used to perform a culture-aware comparison
syntax: Text.StartsWith(text as nullable text, substring as text, optional comparer as nullable function) as nullable logical

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Check if the text "Hello, World" starts with the text "hello".UsagePower Query MText.StartsWith("Hello, World", "hello")OutputfalseExample 2Check if the text "Hello, World" starts with the text "Hello".UsagePower Query MText.StartsWith("Hello, World", "Hello")Outputtrue

remarks: Returns true if text value text starts with text value substring.text: A text value which is to be searchedsubstring: A text value which is the substring to be searched for in substringcomparer: [Optional] A Comparer used for controlling the comparison. For example, Comparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase may be used to perform case-insensitive searchescomparer is a Comparer which is used to control the comparison. Comparers can be used to provide case-insensitive or culture and locale-aware comparisons.The following built-in comparers are available in the formula language:Comparer.Ordinal: Used to perform an exact ordinal comparisonComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase: Used to perform an exact ordinal case-insensitive comparisonComparer.FromCulture: Used to perform a culture-aware comparison

name: Text.ToBinary
description: Encodes the given text value, text, into a binary value using the specified encoding.
syntax: Text.ToBinary(text as nullable text, optional encoding as nullable number, optional includeByteOrderMark as nullable logical) as nullable binary
remarks: Encodes the given text value, text, into a binary value using the specified encoding.

name: Text.ToList
description: Returns a list of character values from the given text value text.
syntax: Text.ToList(text as text) as list

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Create a list of character values from the text "Hello World".UsagePower Query MText.ToList("Hello World")Output{   "H",    "e",    "l",    "l",    "o",    " ",    "W",    "o",    "r",    "l",    "d"}

remarks: Returns a list of character values from the given text value text.

name: Text.Trim
description: Returns the result of removing all leading and trailing whitespace from text value text.
syntax: Text.Trim(text as nullable text, optional trim as any) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Remove leading and trailing whitespace from " a b c d ".UsagePower Query MText.Trim("     a b c d    ")Output"a b c d"

remarks: Returns the result of removing all leading and trailing whitespace from text value text.

name: Text.TrimEnd
description: Removes any occurrences of the characters specified in trimChars from the end of the original text value.
syntax: Text.TrimEnd(text as nullable text, optional trim as any) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Remove trailing whitespace from " a b c d ".UsagePower Query MText.TrimEnd("     a b c d    ")Output"     a b c d"

remarks: Removes any occurrences of the characters specified in trimChars from the end of the original text value.

name: Text.TrimStart
description: Removes any occurrences of the characters in trimChars from the start of the original text value.
syntax: Text.TrimStart(text as nullable text, optional trim as any) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Remove leading whitespace from " a b c d ".Usage**Power Query MText.TrimStart("   a b c d    ")Output"a b c d    "

remarks: Removes any occurrences of the characters in trimChars from the start of the original text value.

name: Text.Upper
description: Returns the result of converting all characters in text to uppercase. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US").
syntax: Text.Upper(text as nullable text, optional culture as nullable text) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Get the uppercase version of "aBcD".UsagePower Query MText.Upper("aBcD")Output"ABCD"

remarks: Returns the result of converting all characters in text to uppercase. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US").

name: Time.EndOfHour
description: Returns the end of the hour represented by dateTime, including fractional seconds. Time zone information is preserved.dateTime: A time, datetime, or datetimezone value from which the end of the hour is calculated.
syntax: Time.EndOfHour(dateTime as any) as any

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Get the end of the hour for 5/14/2011 05:00:00 PM.UsagePower Query MTime.EndOfHour(#datetime(2011, 5, 14, 17, 0, 0))Output#datetime(2011, 5, 14, 17, 59, 59.9999999)Example 2Get the end of the hour for 5/17/2011 05:00:00 PM -7:00.UsagePower Query MTime.EndOfHour(#datetimezone(2011, 5, 17, 5, 0, 0, -7, 0))Output#datetimezone(2011, 5, 17, 5, 59, 59.9999999, -7, 0)

remarks: Returns the end of the hour represented by dateTime, including fractional seconds. Time zone information is preserved.dateTime: A time, datetime, or datetimezone value from which the end of the hour is calculated.

name: Time.From
description: Returns a time value from the given value. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US"). If the given value is null, Time.From returns null. If the given value is time, value is returned. Values of the following types can be converted to a time value:text: A time value from textual representation. Refer to Time.FromText for details.datetime: The time component of the value.datetimezone: The time component of the local datetime equivalent of value.number: A time equivalent to the number of fractional days expressed by value. If value is negative or greater or equal to 1, an error is returned.If value is of any other type, an error is returned.
syntax: Time.From(value as any, optional culture as nullable text) as nullable time

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Convert 0.7575 to a time value.UsagePower Query MTime.From(0.7575)Output#time(18, 10, 48)Example 2Convert #datetime(1899, 12, 30, 06, 45, 12) to a time value.UsagePower Query MTime.From(#datetime(1899, 12, 30, 06, 45, 12))Output#time(06, 45, 12)

remarks: Returns a time value from the given value. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US"). If the given value is null, Time.From returns null. If the given value is time, value is returned. Values of the following types can be converted to a time value:text: A time value from textual representation. Refer to Time.FromText for details.datetime: The time component of the value.datetimezone: The time component of the local datetime equivalent of value.number: A time equivalent to the number of fractional days expressed by value. If value is negative or greater or equal to 1, an error is returned.If value is of any other type, an error is returned.

name: Time.FromText
description: Creates a time value from a textual representation, text. An optional record parameter, options, may be provided to specify additional properties. The record can contain the following fields:Format: A text value indicating the format to use. For more details, go to https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180104 and https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180105. Omitting this field or providing null will result in parsing the time using a best effort.Culture: When Format is not null, Culture controls some format specifiers. For example, in "en-US" "tt" is "AM" or "PM", while in "ar-EG" "tt" is "ص" or "م". When Format is null, Culture controls the default format to use. When Culture is null or omitted, Culture.Current is used.To support legacy workflows, options may also be a text value. This has the same behavior as if options = [Format = null, Culture = options].
syntax: Time.FromText(text as nullable text, optional options as any) as nullable time

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Convert "10:12:31am" into a Time value.UsagePower Query MTime.FromText("10:12:31am")Output#time(10, 12, 31)Example 2Convert "1012" into a Time value.UsagePower Query MTime.FromText("1012")Output#time(10, 12, 00)Example 3Convert "10" into a Time value.UsagePower Query MTime.FromText("10")Output#time(10, 00, 00)

remarks: Creates a time value from a textual representation, text. An optional record parameter, options, may be provided to specify additional properties. The record can contain the following fields:Format: A text value indicating the format to use. For more details, go to https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180104 and https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180105. Omitting this field or providing null will result in parsing the time using a best effort.Culture: When Format is not null, Culture controls some format specifiers. For example, in "en-US" "tt" is "AM" or "PM", while in "ar-EG" "tt" is "ص" or "م". When Format is null, Culture controls the default format to use. When Culture is null or omitted, Culture.Current is used.To support legacy workflows, options may also be a text value. This has the same behavior as if options = [Format = null, Culture = options].

name: Time.Hour
description: Returns the hour component of the provided time, datetime, or datetimezone value, dateTime.
syntax: Time.Hour(dateTime as any) as nullable number

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the hour in #datetime(2011, 12, 31, 9, 15, 36).UsagePower Query MTime.Hour(#datetime(2011, 12, 31, 9, 15, 36))Output9

remarks: Returns the hour component of the provided time, datetime, or datetimezone value, dateTime.

name: Time.Minute
description: Returns the minute component of the provided time, datetime, or datetimezone value, dateTime.
syntax: Time.Minute(dateTime as any) as nullable number

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the minute in #datetime(2011, 12, 31, 9, 15, 36).UsagePower Query MTime.Minute(#datetime(2011, 12, 31, 9, 15, 36))Output15

remarks: Returns the minute component of the provided time, datetime, or datetimezone value, dateTime.

name: Time.Second
description: Returns the second component of the provided time, datetime, or datetimezone value, dateTime.
syntax: Time.Second(dateTime as any) as nullable number

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the second value from a datetime value.UsagePower Query MTime.Second(#datetime(2011, 12, 31, 9, 15, 36.5))Output36.5

remarks: Returns the second component of the provided time, datetime, or datetimezone value, dateTime.

name: Time.StartOfHour
description: Returns the start of the hour represented by dateTime. dateTime must be a time, datetime or datetimezone value.
syntax: Time.StartOfHour(dateTime as any) as any

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the start of the hour for October 10th, 2011, 8:10:32AM.UsagePower Query MTime.StartOfHour(#datetime(2011, 10, 10, 8, 10, 32))Output#datetime(2011, 10, 10, 8, 0, 0)

remarks: Returns the start of the hour represented by dateTime. dateTime must be a time, datetime or datetimezone value.

name: Time.ToRecord
description: Returns a record containing the parts of the given Time value, time.time: A time value for from which the record of its parts is to be calculated.
syntax: Time.ToRecord(time as time) as record

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Convert the #time(11, 56, 2) value into a record containing Time values.UsagePower Query MTime.ToRecord(#time(11, 56, 2))Output[      Hour = 11,      Minute = 56,      Second = 2]

remarks: Returns a record containing the parts of the given Time value, time.time: A time value for from which the record of its parts is to be calculated.

name: Time.ToText
description: Returns a textual representation of time. An optional record parameter, options, may be provided to specify additional properties. culture is only used for legacy workflows. The record can contain the following fields:Format: A text value indicating the format to use. For more details, go to https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180104 and https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180105. Omitting this field or providing null will result in formatting the date using the default defined by Culture.Culture: When Format is not null, Culture controls some format specifiers. For example, in "en-US" "tt" is "AM" or "PM", while in "ar-EG" "tt" is "ص" or "م". When Format is null, Culture controls the default format to use. When Culture is null or omitted, Culture.Current is used.To support legacy workflows, options and culture may also be text values. This has the same behavior as if options = [Format = options, Culture = culture].
syntax: Time.ToText(time as nullable time, optional options as any, optional culture as nullable text) as nullable text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Convert #time(01, 30, 25) into a text value. Result output may vary depending on current culture.UsagePower Query MTime.ToText(#time(11, 56, 2))Output"11:56 AM"Example 2Convert using a custom format and the German culture.UsagePower Query MTime.ToText(#time(11, 56, 2), [Format="hh:mm", Culture="de-DE"])Output"11:56"Example 3Convert using standard time format.UsagePower Query MTime.ToText(#time(11, 56, 2), [Format="T", Culture="de-DE"])Output"11:56:02"

remarks: Returns a textual representation of time. An optional record parameter, options, may be provided to specify additional properties. culture is only used for legacy workflows. The record can contain the following fields:Format: A text value indicating the format to use. For more details, go to https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180104 and https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180105. Omitting this field or providing null will result in formatting the date using the default defined by Culture.Culture: When Format is not null, Culture controls some format specifiers. For example, in "en-US" "tt" is "AM" or "PM", while in "ar-EG" "tt" is "ص" or "م". When Format is null, Culture controls the default format to use. When Culture is null or omitted, Culture.Current is used.To support legacy workflows, options and culture may also be text values. This has the same behavior as if options = [Format = options, Culture = culture].

name: #time
description: Creates a time value from numbers representing the hour, minute, and (fractional) second. Raises an error if these conditions are not true:0 ≤ hour ≤ 240 ≤ minute ≤ 590 ≤ second < 60if hour is 24, then minute and second must be 0
syntax: #time(hour as number, minute as number, second as number) as time
remarks: Creates a time value from numbers representing the hour, minute, and (fractional) second. Raises an error if these conditions are not true:0 ≤ hour ≤ 240 ≤ minute ≤ 590 ≤ second < 60if hour is 24, then minute and second must be 0

name: Type.AddTableKey
description: Adds a key to the given table type.
syntax: Type.AddTableKey(table as type, columns as list, isPrimary as logical) as type
remarks: Adds a key to the given table type.

name: Type.ClosedRecord
description: The given type must be a record type returns a closed version of the given record type (or the same type, if it is already closed)
syntax: Type.ClosedRecord(type as type) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Create a closed version of type [ A = number,…].UsagePower Query MType.ClosedRecord(type [A = number, ...])Outputtype [A = number]

remarks: The given type must be a record type returns a closed version of the given record type (or the same type, if it is already closed)

name: Type.Facets
description: Returns a record containing the facets of type.
syntax: Type.Facets(type as type) as record
remarks: Returns a record containing the facets of type.

name: Type.ForFunction
description: Creates a function type from signature, a record of ReturnType and Parameters, and min, the minimum number of arguments required to invoke the function.
syntax: Type.ForFunction(signature as record, min as number) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Creates the type for a function that takes a number parameter named X and returns a number.UsagePower Query MType.ForFunction([ReturnType = type number, Parameters = [X = type number]], 1)Outputtype function (X as number) as number

remarks: Creates a function type from signature, a record of ReturnType and Parameters, and min, the minimum number of arguments required to invoke the function.

name: Type.ForRecord
description: Returns a type that represents records with specific type constraints on fields.
syntax: Type.ForRecord(fields as record, open as logical) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Dynamically generate a table type.UsagePower Query Mlet    columnNames = {"Name", "Score"},    columnTypes = {type text, type number},    rowColumnTypes = List.Transform(columnTypes, (t) => [Type = t, Optional = false]),    rowType = Type.ForRecord(Record.FromList(rowColumnTypes, columnNames), false)in    #table(type table rowType, {{"Betty", 90.3}, {"Carl", 89.5}})Output#table(    type table [Name = text, Score = number],    {{"Betty", 90.3}, {"Carl", 89.5}})

remarks: Returns a type that represents records with specific type constraints on fields.

name: Type.FunctionParameters
description: Returns a record with field values set to the name of the parameters of type, and their values set to their corresponding types.
syntax: Type.FunctionParameters(type as type) as record

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the types of the parameters to the function (x as number, y as text).UsagePower Query MType.FunctionParameters(type function (x as number, y as text) as any)Output[x = type number, y = type text]

remarks: Returns a record with field values set to the name of the parameters of type, and their values set to their corresponding types.

name: Type.FunctionRequiredParameters
description: Returns a number indicating the minimum number of parameters required to invoke the input type of function.
syntax: Type.FunctionRequiredParameters(type as type) as number

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the number of required parameters to the function (x as number, optional y as text).UsagePower Query MType.FunctionRequiredParameters(type function (x as number, optional y as text) as any)Output1

remarks: Returns a number indicating the minimum number of parameters required to invoke the input type of function.

name: Type.FunctionReturn
description: Returns a type returned by a function type.
syntax: Type.FunctionReturn(type as type) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the return type of () as any).UsagePower Query MType.FunctionReturn(type function () as any)Outputtype any

remarks: Returns a type returned by a function type.

name: Type.Is
description: Determines if a value of type1 is always compatible with type2.
syntax: Type.Is(type1 as type, type2 as type) as logical

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Determine if a value of type number can always also be treated as type any.UsagePower Query MType.Is(type number, type any)OutputtrueExample 2Determine if a value of type any can always also be treated as type number.UsagePower Query MType.Is(type any, type number)Outputfalse

remarks: Determines if a value of type1 is always compatible with type2.

name: Type.IsNullable
description: Returns true if a type is a nullable type; otherwise, false.
syntax: Type.IsNullable(type as type) as logical

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Determine if number is nullable.UsagePower Query MType.IsNullable(type number)OutputfalseExample 2Determine if type nullable number is nullable.UsagePower Query MType.IsNullable(type nullable number)Outputtrue

remarks: Returns true if a type is a nullable type; otherwise, false.

name: Type.IsOpenRecord
description: Returns a logical indicating whether a record type is open.
syntax: Type.IsOpenRecord(type as type) as logical

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Determine if the record type [ A = number, ...] is open.UsagePower Query MType.IsOpenRecord(type [A = number, ...])Outputtrue

remarks: Returns a logical indicating whether a record type is open.

name: Type.ListItem
description: Returns an item type from a list type.
syntax: Type.ListItem(type as type) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find item type from the list {number}.UsagePower Query MType.ListItem(type {number})Outputtype number

remarks: Returns an item type from a list type.

name: Type.NonNullable
description: Returns the non nullable type from the type.
syntax: Type.NonNullable(type as type) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Return the non nullable type of type nullable number.UsagePower Query MType.NonNullable(type nullable number)Outputtype number

remarks: Returns the non nullable type from the type.

name: Type.OpenRecord
description: Returns an opened version of the given record type (or the same type, if it is already opened).
syntax: Type.OpenRecord(type as type) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Create an opened version of type [ A = number].UsagePower Query MType.OpenRecord(type [A = number])Outputtype [A = number, ...]

remarks: Returns an opened version of the given record type (or the same type, if it is already opened).

name: Type.RecordFields
description: Returns a record describing the fields of a record type. Each field of the returned record type has a corresponding name and a value, in the form of a record [ Type = type, Optional = logical ].
syntax: Type.RecordFields(type as type) as record

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Find the name and value of the record [ A = number, optional B = any].UsagePower Query MType.RecordFields(type [A = number, optional B = any])Output[    A = [Type = type number, Optional = false],    B = [Type = type any, Optional = true]]

remarks: Returns a record describing the fields of a record type. Each field of the returned record type has a corresponding name and a value, in the form of a record [ Type = type, Optional = logical ].

name: Type.ReplaceFacets
description: Replaces the facets of type with the facets contained in the record facets.
syntax: Type.ReplaceFacets(type as type, facets as record) as type
remarks: Replaces the facets of type with the facets contained in the record facets.

name: Type.ReplaceTableKeys
description: Returns a new table type with all keys replaced by the specified list of keys.
syntax: Type.ReplaceTableKeys(tableType as type, keys as list) as type
remarks: Returns a new table type with all keys replaced by the specified list of keys.

name: Type.TableColumn
description: Returns the type of the column column in the table type tableType.
syntax: Type.TableColumn(tableType as type, column as text) as type
remarks: Returns the type of the column column in the table type tableType.

name: Type.TableKeys
description: Returns the possibly empty list of keys for the given table type.
syntax: Type.TableKeys(tableType as type) as list
remarks: Returns the possibly empty list of keys for the given table type.

name: Type.TableRow
description: Returns the row type of the specified table type. The result will always be a record type.
syntax: Type.TableRow(table as type) as type

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Return the row type information for a simple table.UsagePower Query Mlet    tableRowType = Type.TableRow(Value.Type(#table({"Column1"}, {})))in    Type.RecordFields(tableRowType)Output[Column1 = [Type = type any, Optional = false]]

remarks: Returns the row type of the specified table type. The result will always be a record type.

name: Type.TableSchema
description: Returns a table describing the columns of tableType.Refer to the documentation for Table.Schema for a description of the resulting table.
syntax: Type.TableSchema(tableType as type) as table
remarks: Returns a table describing the columns of tableType.Refer to the documentation for Table.Schema for a description of the resulting table.

name: Type.Union
description: Returns the union of the types in types.
syntax: Type.Union(types as list) as type
remarks: Returns the union of the types in types.

name: Uri functions
description: Assemble the record query into a URI query string, escaping characters as necessary.
syntax: Uri.BuildQueryString(query as record) as text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Encode a query string which contains some special characters.UsagePower Query MUri.BuildQueryString([a = "1", b = "+$"])Output"a=1&b=%2B%24"

remarks: Assemble the record query into a URI query string, escaping characters as necessary.

name: Uri.Combine
description: Returns an absolute URI that is the combination of the input baseUri and relativeUri.
syntax: Uri.Combine(baseUri as text, relativeUri as text) as text
remarks: Returns an absolute URI that is the combination of the input baseUri and relativeUri.

name: Uri.EscapeDataString
description: Encodes special characters in the input data according to the rules of RFC 3986.
syntax: Uri.EscapeDataString(data as text) as text

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Encode the special characters in "+money$".UsagePower Query MUri.EscapeDataString("+money$")Output"%2Bmoney%24"

remarks: Encodes special characters in the input data according to the rules of RFC 3986.

name: Uri.Parts
description: Returns the parts of the input absoluteUri as a record, containing values such as Scheme, Host, Port, Path, Query, Fragment, UserName and Password.
syntax: Uri.Parts(absoluteUri as text) as record

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Find the parts of the absolute URI "www.adventure-works.com".UsagePower Query MUri.Parts("www.adventure-works.com")Output[    Scheme = "http",    Host = "www.adventure-works.com",    Port = 80,    Path = "/",    Query = [],    Fragment = "",    UserName = "",    Password = ""]Example 2Decode a percent-encoded string.UsagePower Query Mlet    UriUnescapeDataString = (data as text) as text => Uri.Parts("http://contoso?a=" & data)[Query][a]in    UriUnescapeDataString("%2Bmoney%24")Output"+money$"

remarks: Returns the parts of the input absoluteUri as a record, containing values such as Scheme, Host, Port, Path, Query, Fragment, UserName and Password.

name: DirectQueryCapabilities.From
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: DirectQueryCapabilities.From(value as any) as table
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Embedded.Value
description: Accesses a value by name in an embedded mashup.
syntax: Embedded.Value(value as any, path as text) as any
remarks: Accesses a value by name in an embedded mashup.

name: Excel.ShapeTable
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Excel.ShapeTable(table as table, optional options as nullable record) as any
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Graph.Nodes
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Graph.Nodes(graph as record) as list
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Progress.DataSourceProgress
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Progress.DataSourceProgress() as any
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: SqlExpression.SchemaFrom
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: SqlExpression.SchemaFrom(schema as any) as any
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: SqlExpression.ToExpression
description: Converts the provided sql query to M code, with the available identifiers defined by environment. This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: SqlExpression.ToExpression(sql as text, environment as record) as text
remarks: Converts the provided sql query to M code, with the available identifiers defined by environment. This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Value.Add
description: Returns the sum of value1 and value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.
syntax: Value.Add(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as any
remarks: Returns the sum of value1 and value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.

name: Value.Alternates
description: Expresses alternate query plans within a query plan expression obtained through Value.Expression(Value.Optimize(...)). Not intended for other uses.
syntax: Value.Alternates(alternates as list) as any
remarks: Expresses alternate query plans within a query plan expression obtained through Value.Expression(Value.Optimize(...)). Not intended for other uses.

name: Value.As
description: Returns the value if it's compatible with the specified type. This is equivalent to the "as" operator in M, with the exception that it can accept identifier type references such as Number.Type.
syntax: Value.As(value as any, type as type) as any

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Example 1Cast a number to a number.UsagePower Query MValue.As(123, Number.Type)Output123Example 2Attempt to cast a text value to a number.UsagePower Query MValue.As("abc", type number)Output[Expression.Error] We cannot convert the value "abc" to type Number.

remarks: Returns the value if it's compatible with the specified type. This is equivalent to the "as" operator in M, with the exception that it can accept identifier type references such as Number.Type.

name: Value.Compare
description: Returns 1, 0, or -1 based on value1 being greater than, equal to, or less than the value2. An optional comparer function can be provided.
syntax: Value.Compare(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as number
remarks: Returns 1, 0, or -1 based on value1 being greater than, equal to, or less than the value2. An optional comparer function can be provided.

name: Value.Divide
description: Returns the result of dividing value1 by value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.
syntax: Value.Divide(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as any
remarks: Returns the result of dividing value1 by value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.

name: Value.Equals
description: Returns true if value value1 is equal to value value2, false otherwise.
syntax: Value.Equals(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as logical
remarks: Returns true if value value1 is equal to value value2, false otherwise.

name: Value.Expression
description: Returns an abstract syntax tree (AST) that represents the value's expression.
syntax: Value.Expression(value as any) as nullable record
remarks: Returns an abstract syntax tree (AST) that represents the value's expression.

name: Value.Firewall
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Value.Firewall(key as text) as any
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Value.FromText
description: Decodes a value from a textual representation, text, and interprets it as a value with an appropriate type. Value.FromText takes a text value and returns a number, a logical value, a null value, a datetime value, a duration value, or a text value. The empty text value is interpreted as a null value. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US").
syntax: Value.FromText(text as any, optional culture as nullable text) as any
remarks: Decodes a value from a textual representation, text, and interprets it as a value with an appropriate type. Value.FromText takes a text value and returns a number, a logical value, a null value, a datetime value, a duration value, or a text value. The empty text value is interpreted as a null value. An optional culture may also be provided (for example, "en-US").

name: Value.Is
description: Determines whether a value is compatible with the specified type. This is equivalent to the "is" operator in M, with the exception that it can accept identifier type references such as Number.Type.
syntax: Value.Is(value as any, type as type) as logical

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Compare two ways of determining if a number is compatible with type number.UsagePower Query MValue.Is(123, Number.Type) = (123 is number)Outputtrue

remarks: Determines whether a value is compatible with the specified type. This is equivalent to the "is" operator in M, with the exception that it can accept identifier type references such as Number.Type.

name: Value.Lineage
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Value.Lineage(value as any) as any
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Value.Metadata
description: Returns a record containing the input's metadata.
syntax: Value.Metadata(value as any) as any
remarks: Returns a record containing the input's metadata.

name: Value.Multiply
description: Returns the product of multiplying value1 by value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.
syntax: Value.Multiply(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as any
remarks: Returns the product of multiplying value1 by value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.

name: Value.NativeQuery
description: Evaluates query against target using the parameters specified in parameters and the options specified in options.The output of the query is defined by target.target provides the context for the operation described by query.query describes the query to be executed against target. query is expressed in a manner specific to target (for example, a T-SQL statement).The optional parameters value may contain either a list or record as appropriate to supply the parameter values expected by query.The optional options record may contain options that affect the evaluation behavior of query against target. These options are specific to target.
syntax: Value.NativeQuery(target as any, query as text, optional parameters as any, optional options as nullable record) as any
remarks: Evaluates query against target using the parameters specified in parameters and the options specified in options.The output of the query is defined by target.target provides the context for the operation described by query.query describes the query to be executed against target. query is expressed in a manner specific to target (for example, a T-SQL statement).The optional parameters value may contain either a list or record as appropriate to supply the parameter values expected by query.The optional options record may contain options that affect the evaluation behavior of query against target. These options are specific to target.

name: Value.NullableEquals
description: Returns null if either argument value1, value2 is null, otherwise equivalent to Value.Equals.
syntax: Value.NullableEquals(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as nullable logical
remarks: Returns null if either argument value1, value2 is null, otherwise equivalent to Value.Equals.

name: Value.Optimize
description: When used within Value.Expression, if value represents a query that can be optimized, this function indicates that the optimized expression should be returned. Otherwise, value will be passed through with no effect.
syntax: Value.Optimize(value as any) as any
remarks: When used within Value.Expression, if value represents a query that can be optimized, this function indicates that the optimized expression should be returned. Otherwise, value will be passed through with no effect.

name: Value.RemoveMetadata
description: Removes the metadata on the value and returns the original value.
syntax: Value.RemoveMetadata(value as any, optional metaValue as any) as any
remarks: Removes the metadata on the value and returns the original value.

name: Value.ReplaceMetadata
description: Replaces the metadata on a value with the new metadata record provided and returns the original value with the new metadata attached.
syntax: Value.ReplaceMetadata(value as any, metaValue as any) as any
remarks: Replaces the metadata on a value with the new metadata record provided and returns the original value with the new metadata attached.

name: Value.ReplaceType
description: Replaces the value's type with the provided type.
syntax: Value.ReplaceType(value as any, type as type) as any

examples.title: Example
examples.code: Replace the default type of a record with a more specific type.UsagePower Query MType.RecordFields(    Value.Type(        Value.ReplaceType(            [Column1 = 123],            type [Column1 = number]        )    ))[Column1][Type]Outputtype number

remarks: Replaces the value's type with the provided type.

name: Value.Subtract
description: Returns the difference of value1 and value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.
syntax: Value.Subtract(value1 as any, value2 as any, optional precision as nullable number) as any
remarks: Returns the difference of value1 and value2. An optional precision parameter may be specified, by default Precision.Double is used.

name: Value.Traits
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Value.Traits(value as any) as table
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Value.Type
description: Returns the type of the given value.
syntax: Value.Type(value as any) as type
remarks: Returns the type of the given value.

name: Value.VersionIdentity
description: Returns the version identity of the value, or null if it doesn't have a version.
syntax: Value.VersionIdentity(value as any) as any
remarks: Returns the version identity of the value, or null if it doesn't have a version.

name: Value.Versions
description: Returns a navigation table containing the available versions of value.
syntax: Value.Versions(value as any) as table
remarks: Returns a navigation table containing the available versions of value.

name: Value.ViewError
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Value.ViewError(errorRecord as record) as record
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Value.ViewFunction
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Value.ViewFunction(function as function) as function
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: Variable.Value
description: This function is intended for internal use only.
syntax: Variable.Value(identifier as text) as any
remarks: This function is intended for internal use only.

name: #binary
description: Creates a binary value from a list of numbers or a base 64 encoded text value.
syntax: #binary(value as any) as any

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: A list of numbers or base 64 encoded text value

examples.description: Create a binary value from a list of numbers
examples.code: #binary({0x48, 0x65, 0x6C, 0x6C, 0x6F})

remarks: Creates a binary value from a list of numbers or a base 64 encoded text value.

name: #date
description: Creates a date value from whole numbers representing the year, month, and day.
syntax: #date(year as number, month as number, day as number) as date
remarks: Raises an error if the date values are not valid.

name: #datetime
description: Creates a datetime value from numbers representing the year, month, day, hour, minute, and second.
syntax: #datetime(year as number, month as number, day as number, hour as number, minute as number, second as number) as datetime

examples.description: Create a datetime for noon on January 1, 2020

remarks: Creates a datetime value from numbers representing the year, month, day, hour, minute, and (fractional) second.

name: #datetimezone
description: Creates a datetimezone value from numbers representing date, time, and timezone offset components.
syntax: #datetimezone(year as number, month as number, day as number, hour as number, minute as number, second as number, offsetHours as number, offsetMinutes as number) as datetimezone

examples.description: Create a datetimezone for noon EST on January 1, 2020

remarks: Creates a datetimezone value with timezone offset information.

name: #duration
description: Creates a duration value from numbers representing days, hours, minutes, and seconds.
syntax: #duration(days as number, hours as number, minutes as number, seconds as number) as duration

parameters.name: seconds
parameters.description: The number of seconds (can be fractional)

examples.description: Create a duration of 1 day, 2 hours, 30 minutes
examples.code: #duration(1, 2, 30, 0)

remarks: Creates a duration value from numbers representing days, hours, minutes, and (fractional) seconds.

name: #table
description: Creates a table value from columns and rows.
syntax: #table(columns as any, rows as any) as any

parameters.name: columns
parameters.description: List of column names, table type, number of columns, or null

parameters.name: rows
parameters.description: List of lists, where each element contains column values for a single row

examples.description: Create a simple table with names and scores
examples.code: #table({"Name", "Score"}, {{"Betty", 90.3}, {"Carl", 89.5}})

remarks: The columns value can be a list of column names, a table type, a number of columns, or null. The rows value is a list of lists.

name: #time
description: Creates a time value from numbers representing the hour, minute, and second.
syntax: #time(hour as number, minute as number, second as number) as time

parameters.name: hour
parameters.description: The hour (0 ≤ hour ≤ 24, if 24 then minute and second must be 0)

parameters.name: second
parameters.description: The second (0 ≤ second < 60, can be fractional)

remarks: Raises an error if hour is 24 and minute or second are not 0.
